title: Projection Area of 3D Shapes
question_content:
You are given an n x n grid where we place some 1 x 1 x 1 cubes that are axis-aligned with the x, y, and z axes.

Each value v = grid[i][j] represents a tower of v cubes placed on top of the cell (i, j).

We view the projection of these cubes onto the xy, yz, and zx planes.

A projection is like a shadow, that maps our 3-dimensional figure to a 2-dimensional plane. We are viewing the "shadow" when looking at the cubes from the top, the front, and the side.

Return the total area of all three projections.

 

Example 1:

Input: grid = [[1,2],[3,4]]
Output: 17
Explanation: Here are the three projections ("shadows") of the shape made with each axis-aligned plane.

Example 2:

Input: grid = [[2]]
Output: 5

Example 3:

Input: grid = [[1,0],[0,2]]
Output: 8

 

Constraints:

  • n == grid.length == grid[i].length
  • 1 <= n <= 50
  • 0 <= grid[i][j] <= 50

solutions.title: c-java-python-straight-forward-one-pass
11-line-1-pass-java-and-1-liner-python-3-codes-w-explanation-of-the-problem
python-1-liner
ez-python-code
solutions.content:
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
		# Think as looking in a 3-D model from top, front, and side.
        top = sum([1 for g in grid for l in g if l > 0])
        front = sum([max(g) for g in grid])
        side = sum([max(g) for g in zip(*grid)])
        return top + front + side
```

I think to truly understand a problem is very important after I've solved some easy problems in leetcode.

My thinking process is read through problems mutiple times(English is not my first language), and try to come up with my own example.

For this problem, I'm glad they have a sweet diagram with unique numbers so I have visual help to understand why such example has such output. 

Then you will know how to implement solution after you know how to come up with good examples.

solutions.title: simple-easy-solution-by-python-3
solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        xy = sum(i > 0 for s in grid for i in s)
        xz = sum(max(s) for s in grid)
        yz = sum(max(s[i] for s in grid) for i in range(len(grid)))
        return xy + xz + yz
```

solutions.content:
```
def projectionArea(self, grid):
        # Explanation:
		# 1) sum(map(max,grid))                       the sum of the max of all rows
        # 2) sum(map(max,zip(*grid)))                 the sum of the max of all columns
        # 3) sum(map(len, grid)) if element!=0        the number of squares which have at least one cube

        return sum(map(len, [[row for row in col if row] for col in grid])) + sum(map(max,grid)) + sum(map(max,zip(*grid)))
```

```
def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
	xy = sum(1 for row in grid for v in row if v)    # for xy projection count non-zero values
    xz = sum(max(row) for row in grid)               # for xz - it is the sum of the max values in each row
    yz = sum(max(col) for col in zip(*grid))         # for yz - it is the sum of the max values in each column

```
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: int
        """
        xy = sum([len([i for i in g if i != 0]) for g in grid])
        zx = sum([max(g) for g in grid])
        yz = sum([max(g) for g in list(zip(*grid))])
        
        return xy + yz + zx
```

solutions.content:
```
# to calculate area from top -> count all non zero values
# to calculate area from front -> take sum of max from each row
# to calculate area from side -> take sum of max from each column
area_from_top = 0
area_from_front = 0
area_from_side = 0

for row in grid:
	for v in row:
		area_from_top += v > 0

for row in grid:
	area_from_front += max(row)

for j in range(len(grid[0])):
	max_v = 0
	for i in range(len(grid)):
		max_v = max(max_v, grid[i][j])
	area_from_side += max_v

return area_from_top + area_from_front + area_from_side
```

```
# @param {Integer[][]} grid
# @return {Integer}
def projection_area(grid)
  grid.sum(&:max) + grid.transpose.sum(&:max) + grid.flatten(1).count(&:nonzero?)
```

solutions.content:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/f073a91b-41c7-4147-a448-ba11955f6036_1690547961.407219.png)

```
"""
What does each projection mean?

- The xz projection is the view from the y-axis (one side).

- The yz projection is the view from the x-axis (other side).

- The xy projection is the view fromthe z-axis (top-down).
"""

class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        # Declare variables to store the areas for each projection.
        area_xz = area_xy = 0
        heights_yz = [0 for _ in grid[0]] # List to store max height of each column.
        
        # Calculate the areas for each projection.
        for r in range(len(grid)):
            # Add the max height of each row.
            area_xz += max(grid[r])
            for c in range(len(grid[0])):
                # Update the max height of each column.
                heights_yz[c] = max(heights_yz[c], grid[r][c])
                
                # Tower exists at this coordinate.
                if grid[r][c] > 0:
                    # Add 1 to the area of the top-down projection.
                    area_xy += 1
                    
        # Return the sum of the areas for each projection.
        return area_xz + sum(heights_yz) + area_xy
```

```
"""

        # Declare variables to store the areas for each projection.
        area_xz = area_xy = 0
```

```
/**
 * @param {number[][]} grid
 * @return {number}
 */
var projectionArea = function(grid) {
    let result = 0; // initialize result to zero
    for (let i = 0; i < grid.length; i++) { // loop through the every element of array grid
        let x = y = 0; // initialize x and y to zero
        for (let j = 0; j < grid.length; j++) { // loop through the every element of array grid
            x = Math.max(x, grid[i][j]); // find max from grid row
            y = Math.max(y, grid[j][i]); // find max from grid column
            if(grid[i][j] > 0) result++; // if grid[i][j] is greater than zero then increase result
        }
        result += x + y; // add x and y to result
    }
    return result; // return result
};
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
The `projectionArea` function calculates the total projection area of a 3D grid represented as a 2D list. It computes the projection area by considering three directions: z-axis, x-axis, and y-axis.

1. Counting the non-zero elements (`z`): It counts the number of non-zero elements in the grid, representing the projection area from the z-axis direction.

2. Calculating the sum of the maximum values for each row (`x`): It finds the maximum value in each row and sums them up, representing the projection area from the x-axis direction.

3. Calculating the sum of the maximum values for each column (`y`): It transposes the grid, finds the maximum value in each column, and sums them up, representing the projection area from the y-axis direction.

Finally, the function returns the sum of `x`, `y`, and `z`, which represents the total projection area of the 3D grid.

By considering the height values in different directions, the function provides a concise measure of the overall projection area, offering insights into the shape and prominence of the 3D structure.


<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
Considering the steps above, the overall time complexity of the projectionArea function is O(n^2).

- Space complexity:
Considering the steps above, the overall space complexity of the projectionArea function is O(n^2).

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        z = len([x for sublist in grid for x in sublist if x != 0])
        x = sum([max(row) for row in grid])
        y = sum([max(column) for column in zip(*grid)])
        return x+y+z
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
There are three planes we care about.

The ground has a shadow for any cell that has at least 1 block stacked on it. So we just count the number of grid cells that are nonzero.

Then, one side plane projection will have a shadow for the tallest tower in the rows of grid. So we get the maximum element of each row in grid, and sum them.

Finally, the other side plane has a shadow for the tallest tower in the columns of grid. So we get the maximum element of each column in grid and sum them. 


# Approach
For the ground shadow, the position of each cell is irrelevant, so we can just flat_map the entire grid.

For the row shadow, we can iterate over rows and take the max in O(1) space.

For the col shadow, we need to actually iterate over the column index and map to index into the row.


# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n^2), we have to iterate over the entire grid a constance number of times.

- Space complexity: O(1), we perform no heap allocations.

# Code
```
impl Solution {
    pub fn projection_area(grid: Vec<Vec<i32>>) -> i32 {
        let ground: i32 = grid
            .iter()
            .flat_map(|row| row.iter())
            .map(|&cell| if cell > 0 { 1 } else { 0 })
            .sum();

        let row_shadow : i32 = grid
        .iter()
        .map(|row| row.iter().copied().max().unwrap_or_default())
        .sum();

        let col_shadow: i32 = (0..grid.len())
        .map(|j| grid.iter().map(|row| row[j]).max().unwrap_or_default())
        .sum();

        ground + row_shadow + col_shadow
    }
}
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
This is my first time sharing a solution, just started programming in python. 

# Approach
I've tried to do the problem in the easiest way as possible, to help those who are having a difficult time solving it.
First things first, let's understand the problem:
It ask us the "total area of the three projections". The projectios are calculated by adding the shadows of 1 x 1 x 1 cubes "cast" against a wall. In other words, we'll get the perimeter of a given diretion.

Now, to the input:
We are given a matrix, with each number representing the amount of cubes in each cell, where grid[0] represents the first row and grid[i] represents the ith row and grid[][j] represents the jth column
exs:
```
                             |3  4|
grid = [[1,2],[3,4]]  <=>    |1  2|
                          

                                     |2  3  6|
grid = [[7,0,1],[0,0,3],[2,3,6]] <=> |0  0  3|
                                     |7  0  1|
                                     
```
With all that said, now we only need to code it:
X\xD7Y projection:
It's a view from above projection, which means we'll only need to count those cells were we have squares over. This way, we`ll count each cell that is different than 0. using -row.count(0) to exclude the zeros or cel>0 which will only be True(hence 1) if greater than 0.

X\xD7Z projection:
Since each row in grid is a representention of a X\xD7Y, we only need the max value from each one to find the shadow cast on Z.

Y\xD7Z projection:
the same principle of X\xD7Z however we cannot easily acess the columnn values. For that reason will iterate over each row and then will get the max value from the same position.
(grid[row][0], grid[row][1], grid[row][2])

Or we can transpose the matrix and then sum the rows
```
|g  h  i|      transpose    |g  d  a|
|d  e  f|         <=>       |h  e  b|
|a  b  c|                   |i  f  c|
```
Output:
In the end, just sum the area from all the shadows.




# Code
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        #xy
        a = sum([len(row) - row.count(0) for row in grid])
        #xz 
        b = sum([max(row) for row in grid])
        #yz
        c= []
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        ans = len(grid) * len(grid[0])
        ic = [0] * len(grid[0])
        for i in grid:
            ans += max(i)
            for m,n in enumerate(i):
                if n == 0:
                    ans -= 1
                if n > ic[m]:
                    ic[m] = n
        ans += sum(ic)
        return ans

```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Top shadow = no. of cell that is not 0.
2. Front shadow = max of each row
3. Side shadow = max of each col

Iterate through the list and find each of these shadow.
Return sum of 3.

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: int
        """

        n = len(grid)

        top, front, side = 0, 0, 0

        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(n):
                if grid[i][j] > 0: top += 1

        for i in range(n):
            top += max(grid[i])

        for j in range(n):
            s = 0
            for i in range(n):
                s = max(s, grid[i][j])
            side += s

        return top + front + side
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

`xy` plane is simple - just count the number of non-zero `grid[i][j]` elements.
`xz` is also quite simple - it corresponds to the sum of max numbers in each inner array.
`yz` is little harder - it's the sum of the max numbers in each index positions in each nested array.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n^3 + n^2 + n)$$
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        xy = len([item for elem in grid for item in elem if item != 0])
        xz = sum([max(item) for item in grid])
        yz = sum([max(elem) for elem in [[item[i] for item in grid] for i in range(len(grid[0]))]])
        return xy + xz + yz
```


solutions.title: one-liner-python-solution
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Here,

xy projection will be sum of length of each sublist present in main list provided that the sublist will only contain non-zero elements. So, if the sublist consists zeros, eliminate them iteratively.

xz projection will be sum of maximum element present in a row/sublist

yz projection will be sum of maximum element present in a column, i.e. maximum element present in jth column

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: int
        """
        return sum([len(x3) for x3 in [[y for y in x if y>0] for x in grid]])+sum([max(x) for x in grid])+sum(list(map(max, zip(*grid))))
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition, Approach
Area of xy is 1 per element with value nonzero.
Area of xz is the sum of the max value per row of the grid.
Area of yz is the sum of the max value per col of the grid.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
- Space complexity: O(1)

# Code
```
# @param {Integer[][]} grid
# @return {Integer}
def projection_area(grid)
  xy_area = grid.flatten.count{ |v| v != 0  }
  (0...grid.size).reduce(xy_area) do |area, i|
    xz_i_area = grid[i].max
    yz_i_area = grid.map{ _1[i] }.max
    area + xz_i_area + yz_i_area
  end
end
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Did what problem said.

# Approach
Adding the blocks from point of view
1. taking whole space of grid (m*n).
2. Counting and removing zeros as they will not take area when look from above(XY)
3. Getting the max value from each row and adding to result it will give area when seen from left(XZ).
4. Transpose whole matrix (changing rows to column) and do the same operation as did in 3rd step it will give area from upper part (YZ).

I have written axis according to the description might be different for you but will get the same answer.
 

# Code
```

class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        c=len(grid)*len(grid[0])
        for i in range(len(grid)):
            c-=grid[i].count(0)
        for i in range(len(grid)):
            c+=max(grid[i])
        grid=list(zip(*grid))
        for i in range(len(grid)):
            c+=max(grid[i])
        return c
        
```

solutions.content:
XY:
-Count non-zero grid[i][j] elements.

ZX:
-For every row (grid[i]), find the maximum element.

YZ:
-For every column, find the maximum element.


```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):

        count = 0 

        for i in range(len(grid)):
            count += max(grid[i]) #zx
            for j in range(len(grid[i])):
                if grid[i][j] > 0: #xy
                    count += 1

        #yz
        for j in range(len(grid[0])):
            max_column = 0
            for i in range(len(grid)):
                max_column = max(max_column, grid[i][j])
            count += max_column
            
        return count

```

- Time complexity:

- Space complexity:

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: int
        """
        m, n = len(grid), len(grid[0])
        mat_t = [[grid[r][c] for r in range(m)] for c in range(n)]
        area_xy = sum(1 for row in grid for v in row if v)
        area_xz = sum(max(row) for row in grid)
        area_yz = sum(max(row) for row in mat_t)
        return area_xy + area_xz + area_yz

    
        
```

solutions.content:
If you look closely the top is sum of all numbers which is not 0. As each block is of 1x1 size to total area of top is number of block with non zero size

Coming to right side ZX plane - the shadow is max values of all lists inside the grid (as smaller block will be covered in shawdow of larger ones)

Lastly for left size that is ZY plane - shadow is always the max of each columns. So to get each column's max we are using a nested for loop.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(n^2) since we are using nested loop in two of the three faces

- Space complexity:
O(1) since we are using 3 variables

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        tot = 0
        n = len(grid)
        top = sum(grid[i][j] != 0 for i in range(n) for j in range(n))
        right = sum(max(grid[i]) for i in range(n))
        left = sum(max(grid[i][j] for i in range(n)) for j in range(n))

        return right+top+left


```

solutions.title: python-solution-by-finding-non-zero-and-maximums
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Bottom: the number of non-zeros
One side: sum of row maximums
The other side: sum of col maximums


# Complexity
- Time complexity: `O(n^2)`
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: `O(n)`
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```python
class Solution:
    def projectionArea(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
        n = sum(x != 0 for row in grid for x in row)
        row_max = [max(row) for row in grid]
        col_max = [max(col) for col in zip(*grid)]
        return n + sum(row_max) + sum(col_max)
```

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def projectionArea(self, grid):
        """
        :type grid: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: int
        """
        import numpy as np
        grid = np.array(grid)
        return (grid != 0).sum() + grid.max(axis=0).sum() + grid.max(axis=1).sum()
```

can any body explain me the means of the first input?

If anyone still has issue with this:
grid = [[1,2],[3,4]] is where each element in the grid is a row and each element within each row is a cell with the amount of blocks stacked on top of each other. So in this example we have the first row with a single 1x1x1 block next to 2 blocks (all blocks are 1x1x1 units so 1unit^3) and below that we have another row, since 3 is in the same position [0] in the row list as 1 (also [0]), then they are in the same column. 

a visual 2D-bird's-eyeview representation of this would be like Kapple (user below) described it:
[[1,2],
[3,4]]
where each number represents a height in units, which correlates with the amount of blocks stacked up, 0 being no blocks being there. The problem is asking you to return the amount of 'visible' 1x1 2D squares that make up the surface area of each 3D figure/shape.

Hope this helped! glhf <3

Instead of looking at the matrix in inline like this [[2,3,2],[2,1,2],[2,2,2]] look at it using a square as below:
[2,3,2],
[2,1,2],
[2,2,2]

Consider all the numbers as a building of that height. If it is 0 then there is no building at that place. 
What you have to calculate is the shadow the buildings will create if the light is thrown from the top, front, and side. 
From the top - since all the numbers are > 0 shadow length = 3x3 = 9.
From the front - 1st row is having 3 as max height, 2nd row is having 2, and 3rd row is also having 2. = 7
From the side - 1st column is having 2 as max height, 2nd column is having 3, and 3rd column is also having 2. = 7
Total = 9 + 7 + 7 = 23
thanks mate

If you don't understand the given examples:
grid [x][y]: x, y is coordinate on the ground.
grid[x][y] = c -> there are c cubes on the ground at position [x][y]

Example 1:
`grid = [[2]]` => `5`
`grid[0][0] = 2` : position with coordinate [0][0]: there are 2 cubes:
- there is 1 location on x that have cube [0][0] -> shadow on x = 1
- there are 2 cubes stacked, height of the columns is 2 -> shadow on y, z are equal = 2

Example 2: `grid = [[1,0],[0,2]]` => `8`
```

grid[0][0] = 1
grid[0][1] = 0
grid[1][0] = 0
grid[1][1] = 2
````
-> 3 cube in total
shadow on x: there are 2 positions on the ground that have cube:  `[0,0], [1,1]` => `shadow = 2`
shadow on y:  get max value of coordinate
    compare value with the same [y]
    `max(grid[0][0], grid[1][0]) + max(grid[0][1], grid[1][1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
shadow on z:
    compare value with the same[x]
    `max(grid[0]) + max(grid[1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
-> total_shadow = 8

`grid[0][0] = 2` : position with coordinate [0][0]: there are 2 cubes:
- there is 1 location on x that have cube [0][0] -> shadow on x = 1
- there are 2 cubes stacked, height of the columns is 2 -> shadow on y, z are equal = 2

Example 2: `grid = [[1,0],[0,2]]` => `8`
```
grid =  [[1,0], [0,2]]
grid[0][0] = 1
grid[0][1] = 0
grid[1][0] = 0
grid[1][1] = 2
````
-> 3 cube in total
shadow on x: there are 2 positions on the ground that have cube:  `[0,0], [1,1]` => `shadow = 2`
shadow on y:  get max value of coordinate
    compare value with the same [y]
    `max(grid[0][0], grid[1][0]) + max(grid[0][1], grid[1][1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
shadow on z:
    compare value with the same[x]
    `max(grid[0]) + max(grid[1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
-> total_shadow = 8

Why do people write that tasks should be clear and that they would leave the interview if they were given such a confusing task. Firstly, you grow only when you overcome difficulties, what is the point in tasks if you understand them all and can solve them without problems. Understanding the task is also an obstacle that you need to overcome in order to become stronger. As for work, don't worry, if you leave, then there will be a few hundred more people in your place who can understand and solve the problem. I advise you to leave the interview only in one case, if there is an Asian there. There's no chance to get job

If anyone still has issue with this:
grid = [[1,2],[3,4]] is where each element in the grid is a row and each element within each row is a cell with the amount of blocks stacked on top of each other. So in this example we have the first row with a single 1x1x1 block next to 2 blocks (all blocks are 1x1x1 units so 1unit^3) and below that we have another row, since 3 is in the same position [0] in the row list as 1 (also [0]), then they are in the same column. 

a visual 2D-bird's-eyeview representation of this would be like Kapple (user below) described it:
[[1,2],
[3,4]]
where each number represents a height in units, which correlates with the amount of blocks stacked up, 0 being no blocks being there. The problem is asking you to return the amount of 'visible' 1x1 2D squares that make up the surface area of each 3D figure/shape.

Hope this helped! glhf <3

Instead of looking at the matrix in inline like this [[2,3,2],[2,1,2],[2,2,2]] look at it using a square as below:
[2,3,2],
[2,1,2],
[2,2,2]

Consider all the numbers as a building of that height. If it is 0 then there is no building at that place. 
What you have to calculate is the shadow the buildings will create if the light is thrown from the top, front, and side. 
From the top - since all the numbers are > 0 shadow length = 3x3 = 9.
From the front - 1st row is having 3 as max height, 2nd row is having 2, and 3rd row is also having 2. = 7
From the side - 1st column is having 2 as max height, 2nd column is having 3, and 3rd column is also having 2. = 7
Total = 9 + 7 + 7 = 23
thanks mate

where each number represents a height in units, which correlates with the amount of blocks stacked up, 0 being no blocks being there. The problem is asking you to return the amount of 'visible' 1x1 2D squares that make up the surface area of each 3D figure/shape.

Hope this helped! glhf <3

Instead of looking at the matrix in inline like this [[2,3,2],[2,1,2],[2,2,2]] look at it using a square as below:
[2,3,2],
[2,1,2],
[2,2,2]

Consider all the numbers as a building of that height. If it is 0 then there is no building at that place. 
What you have to calculate is the shadow the buildings will create if the light is thrown from the top, front, and side. 
From the top - since all the numbers are > 0 shadow length = 3x3 = 9.
From the front - 1st row is having 3 as max height, 2nd row is having 2, and 3rd row is also having 2. = 7
From the side - 1st column is having 2 as max height, 2nd column is having 3, and 3rd column is also having 2. = 7
Total = 9 + 7 + 7 = 23

If you don't understand the given examples:
grid [x][y]: x, y is coordinate on the ground.
grid[x][y] = c -> there are c cubes on the ground at position [x][y]

Example 1:
`grid = [[2]]` => `5`
`grid[0][0] = 2` : position with coordinate [0][0]: there are 2 cubes:
- there is 1 location on x that have cube [0][0] -> shadow on x = 1
- there are 2 cubes stacked, height of the columns is 2 -> shadow on y, z are equal = 2

Example 2: `grid = [[1,0],[0,2]]` => `8`
```
grid =  [[1,0], [0,2]]
grid[0][0] = 1
grid[0][1] = 0
grid[1][0] = 0
grid[1][1] = 2
````
-> 3 cube in total
shadow on x: there are 2 positions on the ground that have cube:  `[0,0], [1,1]` => `shadow = 2`
shadow on y:  get max value of coordinate
    compare value with the same [y]
    `max(grid[0][0], grid[1][0]) + max(grid[0][1], grid[1][1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
shadow on z:
    compare value with the same[x]
    `max(grid[0]) + max(grid[1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
-> total_shadow = 8

grid = [[1,2],[3,4]] is where each element in the grid is a row and each element within each row is a cell with the amount of blocks stacked on top of each other. So in this example we have the first row with a single 1x1x1 block next to 2 blocks (all blocks are 1x1x1 units so 1unit^3) and below that we have another row, since 3 is in the same position [0] in the row list as 1 (also [0]), then they are in the same column. 

a visual 2D-bird's-eyeview representation of this would be like Kapple (user below) described it:
[[1,2],
[3,4]]
where each number represents a height in units, which correlates with the amount of blocks stacked up, 0 being no blocks being there. The problem is asking you to return the amount of 'visible' 1x1 2D squares that make up the surface area of each 3D figure/shape.

Hope this helped! glhf <3

Instead of looking at the matrix in inline like this [[2,3,2],[2,1,2],[2,2,2]] look at it using a square as below:
[2,3,2],
[2,1,2],
[2,2,2]

Consider all the numbers as a building of that height. If it is 0 then there is no building at that place. 
What you have to calculate is the shadow the buildings will create if the light is thrown from the top, front, and side. 
From the top - since all the numbers are > 0 shadow length = 3x3 = 9.
From the front - 1st row is having 3 as max height, 2nd row is having 2, and 3rd row is also having 2. = 7
From the side - 1st column is having 2 as max height, 2nd column is having 3, and 3rd column is also having 2. = 7
Total = 9 + 7 + 7 = 23

- there is 1 location on x that have cube [0][0] -> shadow on x = 1
- there are 2 cubes stacked, height of the columns is 2 -> shadow on y, z are equal = 2

Example 2: `grid = [[1,0],[0,2]]` => `8`
```
grid =  [[1,0], [0,2]]
grid[0][0] = 1
grid[0][1] = 0
grid[1][0] = 0
grid[1][1] = 2
````
-> 3 cube in total
shadow on x: there are 2 positions on the ground that have cube:  `[0,0], [1,1]` => `shadow = 2`
shadow on y:  get max value of coordinate
    compare value with the same [y]
    `max(grid[0][0], grid[1][0]) + max(grid[0][1], grid[1][1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
shadow on z:
    compare value with the same[x]
    `max(grid[0]) + max(grid[1])` = `1 + 2` = `3`
-> total_shadow = 8

title: Add to Array-Form of Integer
question_content:
The array-form of an integer num is an array representing its digits in left to right order.

  • For example, for num = 1321, the array form is [1,3,2,1].

Given num, the array-form of an integer, and an integer k, return the array-form of the integer num + k.

 

Example 1:

Input: num = [1,2,0,0], k = 34
Output: [1,2,3,4]
Explanation: 1200 + 34 = 1234

Example 2:

Input: num = [2,7,4], k = 181
Output: [4,5,5]
Explanation: 274 + 181 = 455

Example 3:

Input: num = [2,1,5], k = 806
Output: [1,0,2,1]
Explanation: 215 + 806 = 1021

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= num.length <= 104
  • 0 <= num[i] <= 9
  • num does not contain any leading zeros except for the zero itself.
  • 1 <= k <= 104

solutions.content:
# **Please UPVOTE if you find this post useful :)**

<u><strong>Refer to the following github repsitory for more leetcode solutions<strong></u>
https://github.com/Akshaya-Amar/LeetCodeSolutions

* <u>**COMPLEXITY**</u>
	* **Time: O(max(n, log<sub>10</sub>(k)))**, where **n** is the **length of the array** and **log<sub>10</sub>(k)** is the **number of digits** present in variable `k`.
	* **Space: O(max(n, log<sub>10</sub>(k)))**, not an in-place as we need space equal to the given k or length of array, whichever is maximum between the two, to store the elements.

* <u>**BASIC IDEA**</u>
Basic Idea behind this implementation is to add the num array element one by one with the k
eg:
`num[] = {1, 2, 3}` and `k = 45;`

	* **1<sup>st</sup> Iteration:**
`k += num[len--]` --> k = k + num[2] --> k = 45 + 3 --> k = 48
`list.addFirst(k % 10)` --> list.addFirst(48 % 10) --> list.addFirst(8) --> [8]  
`k /= 10` --> k = k / 10 --> 48 / 10 --> k = 4

	* **2<sup>nd</sup> Iteration:**
`k += num[len--]` --> k = k + num[1] --> k = 4 + 2 --> k = 6
`list.addFirst(k % 10)` --> list.addFirst(6 % 10) --> list.addFirst(6) --> [6, 8]
`k /= 10` --> k = k / 10 --> 6 / 10 --> k = 0

	* **3<sup>rd</sup> Iteration:**
`k += num[len--]` --> k = k + num[0] --> k = 0 + 1 --> k = 1
`list.addFirst(k % 10)` --> list.addFirst(1 % 10) --> list.addFirst(1) --> [1, 6, 8]  **<--- Desired Output**
`k /= 10` --> k = k / 10 --> 1 / 10 --> k = 0

	**Here, the loop will be executed 3 times as (length of num) > (number of digits in k) i.e. O(max(n, log<sub>10</sub>(k))), where n is the length of the array and log<sub>10</sub>(k) is the number of digits**

solutions.content:
# Notes:
- Leetcode provided a simple [solution](https://leetcode.com/problems/add-to-array-form-of-integer/solution/), but it is not efficient. K has 5 digits at most, but A can have 10000 elements. This means that the summation might finish after 5 iterations, but the loop will continue for 10000 times! I added a condition to avoid this.
- I think the purpose of this question is to provide a summation based on elementary school math, and avoid other functions such as 'str', 'int' and 'map'. 
- The Leetcode solution does not work for Python3, but slight changes would make it compatible for both Python/ Python3.


# Python/ Python3 code:
```
        for i in range(len(A) - 1, -1, -1):
            if not K: break
            K, A[i] = divmod(A[i] + K, 10)
        while K:
            K, a = divmod(K, 10)
            A = [a] + A
        return A
```

```
        for i in range(len(A) - 1, -1, -1):
            if not K: break
            K, A[i] = divmod(A[i] + K, 10)
        while K:
            K, a = divmod(K, 10)
            A = [a] + A
        return A
```

solutions.content:
Approach:
1. Convert the list of integers into a single number using ```join()```
2. Explicitly convert the new string into int and add it with ```K```.
3. Convert the sum into string and return it as a list using ```list()```.

```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, A: List[int], K: int) -> List[int]:
        return (list(str(int("".join(map(str, A))) + K)))
```
```
#Runtime: 304ms
#Memory Usage: 14.3MB
```

solutions.title: python3-268-ms-faster-than-96-60-of-python3
solutions.content:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/56149966-d41d-41e2-9bc6-5ee3fcc51014_1676427091.1014879.png)
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        if not num:
            return [int(d) for d in str(k)]
        carry = 0
        res = []
        for i in range(len(num)-1, -1, -1):
            total = num[i] + carry + (k % 10)
            carry = total // 10
            res.append(total % 10)
            k //= 10
        while k > 0:
            total = carry + (k % 10)
            carry = total // 10
            res.append(total % 10)
            k //= 10
        if carry > 0:
            res.append(carry)
        return res[::-1]
```
The main idea of the function is to simulate the addition process for two numbers: the input num and the input k. The addition is performed digit by digit, from right to left, while keeping track of the carry from one digit to the next. The function appends each resulting digit to the res list and returns it at the end.
Here's a step by step description of the code:

1. Define a function addToArrayForm that takes in a list of integers num and an integer k, and returns a list of integers.
1. Check if num is an empty list. If so, convert k to a list of integers and return it.
1. Initialize variables carry and res to 0 and an empty list, respectively.
1. Loop over num in reverse order using the range function. At each iteration:
	1. 	Calculate the sum of the current digit of num, the corresponding digit of k, and the carry using the modulo operator (%).
	1. 	Update the carry by dividing the total by 10 using integer division (//).
	1. 	Append the remainder of the total (i.e., total % 10) to res.
	1. 	Update k by dividing it by 10 using integer division (//).
1. Loop over k while it is greater than 0. At each iteration:
	1. Calculate the sum of the current digit of k and the carry using the modulo operator (%).
	1. Update the carry by dividing the total by 10 using integer division (//).
	1. Append the remainder of the total (i.e., total % 10) to res.
	1. Update k by dividing it by 10 using integer division (//).
1. If the final carry value is greater than 0, append it to res.
1. Return the reversed list res.
solutions.code:
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        if not num:
            return [int(d) for d in str(k)]
        carry = 0
        res = []
        for i in range(len(num)-1, -1, -1):
            total = num[i] + carry + (k % 10)
            carry = total // 10
            res.append(total % 10)
            k //= 10
        while k > 0:
            total = carry + (k % 10)
            carry = total // 10
            res.append(total % 10)
            k //= 10
        if carry > 0:
            res.append(carry)
        return res[::-1]
```

```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, A: 'List[int]', K: 'int') -> 'List[int]':
        A[-1] += K
        i = len(A) - 1
        while i > 0 and A[i] > 9:
            A[i-1] += A[i] // 10
            A[i] = A[i] % 10
            i -= 1
        while A[0] > 9:
            A = [A[0] // 10] + A
            A[1] = A[1] % 10
        return A
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Easy problem with one line solution where `num` list is joined to form an int and then added to `k` and again converted to list.

# Approach
Although its a one-line solution, there are multiple steps involved.
1. Iterating through the `nums` list while converting each element to `str` and then joining them. Now this joined string will be converted to `int`.
2. The `int` obtained in Step-1 will be added to `k` and then the `sum` is again converted to string.
3. Now, iterate over the `sum` string into `list` while converting each element to `int`.

# Complexity
- Time complexity : $$O(log(len(num)^2 + k))$$
- Space complexity : $$O(1)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        return [int(i) for i in str(k+ int(''.join(str(n) for n in num)))]
```

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
- First I converted list into string format in order to make it as number.
- Then I added the num and K and then converted the result into string again to convert from string format to list and assigned to str_list.
- Later converted the str_list into int by using map function and assigned it to final_str_list and returned it.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        s = ""
        for i in num:
            s+=str(i)
        str_list = " ".join(str(int(s)+k)).split()
        final_list = list(map(int,str_list))
        return final_list
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->Using brute force to look.
first for loop is used to convert the list to number.
then we store the acquired number in **s**
Add the k in s then loop the s and enter the digits in empty list named **lst** 
But this new list will have result in reverse order so we will return it by reversing it as **lst[::-1]**

Note: for better understanding take a list containing not more than 2 elements and run through the code.Also you can use jupyter or use print statement after steps how the code is progressing.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def addToArrayForm(self, num, k):
        """
        :type num: List[int]
        :type k: int
        :rtype: List[int]
        """
        s=0
        for i in num:
            s=s*10+i
        s=s+k
        lst=[]
        while(s!=0):
            lst.append(s%10)
            s=s//10
        return lst[::-1]

```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Convert `k` to reversed iterable of digits using `rdigits`.

2. Add backwards, digit by digit with carry, of `num` and `rdigits(k)`

3. Push the results into a queue to un-reverse the sum, and return.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

where, `n is the max length of num and k`

# Code
```python
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: list[int], k: int) -> list[int]:
        def rdigits(n: int) -> Iterable[int]:
            while n: n, r = divmod(n, 10); yield r
        
        def sum_iter(xs: Iterable[int], ys: Iterable[int]) -> Iterable[int]:
            c = 0
            for x, y in zip_longest(xs, ys, fillvalue=0):
                c, s = divmod(x + y + c, 10)
                yield s
            if c: yield c
        
        sum_ = deque()
        sum_.extendleft(sum_iter(reversed(num), rdigits(k)))
        return sum_


```

solutions.content:
# Logic
    Logic of Approach 1 --
        1. Just convert array form to number
        2. Add number + k and store in result
        3. Convert result into Array Form 
        4. Return resultant Array Form

    Logic of Approach 2 -- 
        Repeat this step until reach at 0 index of array
            1. Add k  and array last index value
            2. Do the mod with 10 and division with 10
            3. Store the mod value in that index 
            4. Store the division value in K
            5. Decrement index by 1
        If k still not 0, then
            then add all k in array from in front of num array
        Finally return num array


    If you find hard to understand that you can also watch this video.
    I explained with code :)

    Kindly Upvote if you findit helpful👍.
https://youtu.be/548-VplMrrQ


# Code

```python []
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        # Approach 1,   T.C =  O(max(N,K)) where K = length of str(k)
        
        data = 0
        for val in num:
            data = data*10+val

        data+=k
        res = []
        while data!=0:
            res.append(data%10)
            data//=10
        return res[::-1]
        

        # Approach 2,  T.C = O(max(N,K)) where K = length of str(k)
        
        n = len(num)
        for i in range(n-1,-1,-1):
            num[i],k = (num[i]+k)%10,(num[i]+k)//10
        if k!=0:
            return [int(val) for val in str(k)]+num
        return num
        
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Elementary maths - 123 can be expressed as 1\*100 + 2\*10 + 3\*1

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
From the given array compute the decimal input 

Add that to k

Convert decimal to array

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:

        no, place = 0, 1

        for i in range(len(num)-1, -1, -1):
            no += num[i] * place
            place = place * 10
        
        no += k
        return [int(i) for i in list(str(no))]

```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution(object):
		def addToArrayForm(self, num, k):
			"""
			:type num: List[int]
			:type k: int
			:rtype: List[int]
			"""
```
			return (list(str(int("".join(map(str, num))) + k)))
			
We approach the problem in 3 steps
1. Convert the list of integers into a single number 
2. Convert the string to int and add K to it.
3. Convert the sum into string and return it as string

solutions.content:
**If you got help from this,... Plz Upvote .. it encourage me**
# Code
# Approach 1 Array
```
class Solution(object):
    def addToArrayForm(self, A, K):
        A[-1] += K
        for i in range(len(A) - 1, -1, -1):
            carry, A[i] = divmod(A[i], 10)
            if i: A[i-1] += carry
        if carry:
            A = list(map(int, str(carry))) + A
        return A

```

.

# Approach 2 (By Convert list into number then add and then convert number into digit)
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        # List -> Number
        n = 0
        for ele in num:
            n = (n*10) + ele
        
        n = n+k
        
        # Number -> List
        num = []
        while n > 0:
            num.insert(0, n % 10)  
            n //= 10 
        return num
```

solutions.content:
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        for i in range(len(num) - 1, -1, -1):
            n = (num[i] + k) // 10
            num[i] = (num[i]+ k) % 10
            k = n
        
        while k:
            n = k % 10
            k //= 10
            num = [n] + num
        return num



```

Tip for Java coders: Use LinkedList instead of simple Arraylist. It speeds up the computation time manifolds!
manifolds? \uD83D\uDE05
If using the arraylist, adding at the end and reversing the list before returning would be the better way. But linkedlist still tops that.
thank you, improved from 21% to 100% :D. Almost forgot that addFirst in LinkedList only costs O(1), while ArrayList is O(n)
Thank u sm!

Think about these corner cases: 
num = [9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9], k = 1
num = [0], k = 23
num = [6], k = 809

Lifehack to get last digit from `k`: `k % 10`. Don't forget to delete last digit `k /= 10`. 
**Example: k = 809**
  - 809 % 10 = 9 
  - 809 / 10 = 80
  - 80 % 10 = 0
  - 80 / 10 = 8
  - 8 % 10 = 8
  - 8 / 10 = 0

1) Check case `if k == 0` but index `i still less than num.length`
2) Don't forget to check carry before return. `If (carry == 1) res.add(1)`
3) Will need extra loop before return if `k > 0` in the case `num = [6], k = 809` 

`return res.reverse()`;
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280)  i think it\'s because integer is a 32 bit \nwe need long
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) bro let me know if you find a way\n
[@Preposterone](/Preposterone) Good idea! I did it after main iteration before return

[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) if you\'re iterating from the end and you\'re already at 0th index, then prepend a new element (list.insert(value: 0, index: 0) and continue with your algorithm as before.
This should be a medium level problem
[@2017016](/2017016) try using long brother(still wouldnt work by the way)\n
[@2017016](/2017016) as the number variable overflows , remember range of int .(-2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647)
why so?

If you are just trying to get the number from vector to a variable, then you will run into overflow problem. No variable can hold a number with 10^4 digits. This method would have worked if the constraints were smaller. Think of a different approach. This question is not as easy as it seems.
And then there is python which can very much hold a 10^4 length integer without doing anything particularly fancy :P
At the first glance , I thought this is the easiest problem, but as we say never judge a book by its Cover. Lol.
If you think it is medium level problem , It is!!
[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) In Python, use str() function fail.
[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) I think the difficulty is language dependant as I\'m not sure it would be possible to recreate your naive example in a language like Java or C++
Naah man it is easy tbh. You just have to be aware of the edge cases.

[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) Sorry Dude C++ doesn't have this much flexibility. I tried to convert string to int/long(which you are doing in step 4) using "stoi", "stoll" and other but all gave out of range. So went for the long way :) which wasn't that hard!

no its easy only , until they have some restriction on solving it .
 you can convert num to str , convert str to int add with k , convert to str again , loop and put in array while converting to int and that's the naive way to solve it , if this was not allowed then it is a medium problem
here is naive sol;
        s = ''
        for i in num:
            s+=str(i)
        a =(int(s)) + k 
        a = str(a)
        z = [int(i) for i in a]
        return z
number is too large to store on variable
the storage limit of n exceeds 2^31

Think about these corner cases: 
num = [9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9], k = 1
num = [0], k = 23
num = [6], k = 809

Lifehack to get last digit from `k`: `k % 10`. Don't forget to delete last digit `k /= 10`. 
**Example: k = 809**
  - 809 % 10 = 9 
  - 809 / 10 = 80
  - 80 % 10 = 0
  - 80 / 10 = 8
  - 8 % 10 = 8
  - 8 / 10 = 0

1) Check case `if k == 0` but index `i still less than num.length`
2) Don't forget to check carry before return. `If (carry == 1) res.add(1)`
3) Will need extra loop before return if `k > 0` in the case `num = [6], k = 809` 

`return res.reverse()`;

Tip for Java coders: Use LinkedList instead of simple Arraylist. It speeds up the computation time manifolds!
manifolds? \uD83D\uDE05
If using the arraylist, adding at the end and reversing the list before returning would be the better way. But linkedlist still tops that.
thank you, improved from 21% to 100% :D. Almost forgot that addFirst in LinkedList only costs O(1), while ArrayList is O(n)
Thank u sm!

Think about these corner cases: 
num = [9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9,9], k = 1
num = [0], k = 23
num = [6], k = 809

Lifehack to get last digit from `k`: `k % 10`. Don't forget to delete last digit `k /= 10`. 
**Example: k = 809**
  - 809 % 10 = 9 
  - 809 / 10 = 80
  - 80 % 10 = 0
  - 80 / 10 = 8
  - 8 % 10 = 8
  - 8 / 10 = 0

1) Check case `if k == 0` but index `i still less than num.length`
2) Don't forget to check carry before return. `If (carry == 1) res.add(1)`
3) Will need extra loop before return if `k > 0` in the case `num = [6], k = 809` 

`return res.reverse()`;
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280)  i think it\'s because integer is a 32 bit \nwe need long
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) bro let me know if you find a way\n
[@Preposterone](/Preposterone) Good idea! I did it after main iteration before return

[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) if you\'re iterating from the end and you\'re already at 0th index, then prepend a new element (list.insert(value: 0, index: 0) and continue with your algorithm as before.
This should be a medium level problem
[@2017016](/2017016) try using long brother(still wouldnt work by the way)\n
[@2017016](/2017016) as the number variable overflows , remember range of int .(-2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647)
why so?

If you are just trying to get the number from vector to a variable, then you will run into overflow problem. No variable can hold a number with 10^4 digits. This method would have worked if the constraints were smaller. Think of a different approach. This question is not as easy as it seems.
And then there is python which can very much hold a 10^4 length integer without doing anything particularly fancy :P
At the first glance , I thought this is the easiest problem, but as we say never judge a book by its Cover. Lol.
If you think it is medium level problem , It is!!
[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) In Python, use str() function fail.
[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) I think the difficulty is language dependant as I\'m not sure it would be possible to recreate your naive example in a language like Java or C++
Naah man it is easy tbh. You just have to be aware of the edge cases.

[@AdityaBharat](/AdityaBharat) Sorry Dude C++ doesn't have this much flexibility. I tried to convert string to int/long(which you are doing in step 4) using "stoi", "stoll" and other but all gave out of range. So went for the long way :) which wasn't that hard!

no its easy only , until they have some restriction on solving it .
 you can convert num to str , convert str to int add with k , convert to str again , loop and put in array while converting to int and that's the naive way to solve it , if this was not allowed then it is a medium problem
here is naive sol;
        s = ''
        for i in num:
            s+=str(i)
        a =(int(s)) + k 
        a = str(a)
        z = [int(i) for i in a]
        return z

Easy to understand\n

Every digit past 2^53 will start losing precision which can cause things like erroneous rounding. If you need to work with larger numbers then use `BigInt`: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/BigInt

Adding elements from the left is must efficient. We can do that using linked list or other data structure. In python, we can use $$deque()$$  from $$collections$$. We don't need to import it in **leetcode**. Also we just need to  return this $$deque$$ and it will be accepted.

Every digit past 2^53 will start losing precision which can cause things like erroneous rounding. If you need to work with larger numbers then use `BigInt`: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/BigInt

Adding elements from the left is must efficient. We can do that using linked list or other data structure. In python, we can use $$deque()$$  from $$collections$$. We don't need to import it in **leetcode**. Also we just need to  return this $$deque$$ and it will be accepted.

Because num can represent a number as large as (10**10000) - 1, it is wiser to consider k as if it were a vector<int>/List/your language's version of the list ADT (even if your implementation doesn't actually create a new list ADT to store k). After you start thinking along those lines, the problem is a lot more like "add strings" or "add two numbers".

Why is an ArrayList so much slower than a LinkedList in a Java solution?

```class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        string = ""
        result = []
        for i in num:
            string+=str(i)
        ans = int(string)+k
        for i in str(ans):
            result.append(int(i))
        return result
```
This problem is fine but trivial in some languages
The same as 67

- Problem for large numbers with division, for example:
12630717197566440579/10
-> change to floor division:  sum//=10

"Be careful when doing division. By default, the quotient is turned into float, but float does not support such large numbers. If you get an error message saying float does not support such large numbers, then it means the quotient is too large to be stored in float youll have to use floor division (//)."

```class Solution:
    def addToArrayForm(self, num: List[int], k: int) -> List[int]:
        string = ""
        result = []
        for i in num:
            string+=str(i)
        ans = int(string)+k
        for i in str(ans):
            result.append(int(i))
        return result
```

From 13-15 February challenges on leetcode like: 
`"we are _simpler_ than your girlfriends"`
sheesh
num can be very large, meaning that when it tries to find pow(10, size - 1), it may exceed the limits of primitive types (including double).
we can use yesterday\'s idea as change the given k to an array and do array addition
It should be updated to medium question.\nToo much of corner cases that needed to be taken care.
Not smart enough so this is HELLA ANNOYING to me

Add the numbers like we did we in our schools. We just have to think how to break k in digits and then add it to the elements of the vector from the reverse order.\nWe have to run a loop till array is complete and till carry and k is not equal to zero.\nAdd the digits of k to the last element of the array and maintain a carry.

Python experts: can someone please let me know the TC of this one liner ? 
 My understanding is O(M.N) where join takes O(n) operation and O(m) times to map string to int and vice versa. 

 `return map(int, list(str(int(''.join(map(str, num))) + k)))`

stand at last index of num vector and start adding k to it, once you add k, put sum%k in new ans vector, and then divide sum by 10 to eliminate the last digit which we have just included in the list. After looping over the num vector , you may check if sum>0, i.e if still we have some digit left, so while num>0, simply add it to ans and divide by 10 again.

Now simply return the reversed list
Thats all! quite simple na!! :)

Easy days of leetcode :) Something big to come!!

stand at last index of num vector and start adding k to it, once you add k, put sum%k in new ans vector, and then divide sum by 10 to eliminate the last digit which we have just included in the list. After looping over the num vector , you may check if sum>0, i.e if still we have some digit left, so while num>0, simply add it to ans and divide by 10 again.

Now simply return the reversed list
Thats all! quite simple na!! :)
This problem is very much similar to yesterday\'s daily.
Tips : use LinkedList class and traverse array backwards. K might be greater than num (i.e., log10(k)+1 > num.length), keep that point in mind, after all carry can still be non zero.

Integer only supports till 10^9, but vector has 10^4 numbers, that means you are trying to store a number which is 10^10^4, in int. Try directly adding in the array

Do not use any variable to store the whole number. Start adding each digit from the \'k\' variable from its 1\'s place position directly with the last value of the array and continue the process until either no value of \'k\' remains or whole array is traversed and enter the sum in the new List. Do the same process for either of the condition for itself that is \'k\' remains but array traversal finished or vice-versa. Add a 1 at the end if after all this process we see there still is a carry. Now we have got the List we require but in reverse form. Just reverse the new List and return the List.\n\nHope that this will help.
value of d goes beyond integer range
